content.webTitle: Morris Gleitzman, beloved children's author, meets his new editors – children

fields.headline: Morris Gleitzman, beloved children's author, meets his new editors – children
fields.bodyText: When it comes to talking about his newest editors, beloved children’s author Morris Gleitzman doesn’t have a bad word to say – perhaps because all of the “bad words” he originally put forward have been carefully weighed, considered and, for the most part, cut out. Children are conscientious editors. Gleitzman is used to writing for children. He’s not used to being edited by them, with the possible exception of his own children, who comment on everything he does. But giving kids the opportunity to edit is precisely the point of Early Harvest, the annual publication put out by 100 Story Building, an organisation based in Melbourne that centres around providing opportunities and programs for young writers. Each year, an editorial team of Grade 5 and 6 students comes up with a theme – this year it’s “Dreams” – and then oversee the production of a book filled with short stories, illustrations, games and activities. It’s no small task. “The biggest challenge was having those 200-something submissions and we had to cut it down to 12,” says Nivain Don, one of the members of the editorial committee. “And it’s hard to select the stories because all of them were so good,” adds fellow editor Airin Vinod. The tough decisions didn’t end there. In addition to work submitted by fellow schoolchildren, Early Harvest also invites established authors and illustrators to submit work. They are then subjected to the same level of scrutiny as everyone else. This year, beloved author and Australian Children’s Laureate Morris Gleitzman happily put himself at the mercy of the editorial committee. “I contributed something a little different,” says Gleitzman. “What it is is a list of the first sentences of all of my books, all 40 books, and another 20 or so [from short stories].” The editorial committee knew who Gleitzman was before working with him. This didn’t make them hold back on their edits, though. “They certainly didn’t diminish their responsibility to turning out the best magazine they could through any sense of deference or ‘oh, he’s a professional author so we must treat his work with kid gloves’,” Gleitzman says. “They were very professional.” “Children of this age are not precious or reverent. They are always vocal about whether they like something or not, it’s just a rare occasion that their opinion can affect the outcome in such a huge way,” says Simon Conlon, the Programs Manager at 100 Story Building. “Children and young people are sharp and opinionated and we try to give them the choice to decide where their creative projects should go … Their ideas are inevitably better than any of ours.” Gleitzman mentions how the editorial team were quite critical of one of his lines from an early book. “They felt wasn’t really a good opener,” he laughs. “I did feel moved to point out to them that the book whose first sentence they were saying wasn’t a terribly good opener had sold about 150,000 copies.” He pauses. “But I also acknowledged that, possibly, had they been editing the book when it was first published … maybe it would have sold more than 150,000 copies.” The editors cut Gleitzman’s list of 65 opening lines down to 61. The biggest reason for cutting the list was, according to Vinod, “because it had bad language”. “One of the first sentences of a short story contained the word ‘bosoms’,” says Gleitzman. “They used exactly the same wording as so many of the world’s biggest publishing houses do,” he says with a laugh. “‘We just feel that this isn’t exactly right for our readership’.” So they negotiated. “We made a deal,” says Vinod. “He said we could change some [lines],” says Don, but sometimes when a compromise couldn’t be met, they cut lines completely. “Horse trading!” Gleitzman says. “I haven’t seen the final magazine yet but I think I traded a ‘bosoms’ for ‘scum’.” Gleitzman emphasises the importance of giving children the chance to be in charge creating something in this way. “I think handing over a whole publishing structure like this to young people is a really good way of giving them extra dimensions to their own writing,” he says. “Children’s point of view is different to adult’s point of view,” Vinod says. “Children have different thoughts and ideas and it’s good children can express their opinion.” • Early Harvest 7 is launching on 10 November
